CFM_GaleAlone.synopsis: Triggers either as an OOM or an AOM when Elminster is already in the camp, or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).
CFM_GaleAlone.how_to_trigger: With Gale Companion without an Avatar available, or with Gale as Avatar:- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to SCL_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_SCL_975ef355-b68e-4061-bda8-b774e8ff552fContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to CRE_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_CRE_f5a225ef-d123-449f-98e2-53309a21979bContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.- Go to SCL_Main_A- Queue night NIGHT_ORI_Gale_ElminsterVisit

CFM_GaleCom.synopsis: Gale is a Companion.This dialogue can trigger as COM (if the players approach Elminster with Gale as a companion), as a regular dialogue (if the players approach Elminster while Companion Gale is in the camp) or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).It can trigger in either Creche or SCL.
CFM_GaleCom.how_to_trigger: - Give Gale at least one magic item, go to SCL_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_SCL_975ef355-b68e-4061-bda8-b774e8ff552fContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to CRE_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_CRE_f5a225ef-d123-449f-98e2-53309a21979bContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Go to SCL_Main_A- Queue night NIGHT_ORI_Gale_ElminsterVisit

CFM_GaleAlone_29.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_29.context: CinematicNodeContext: Glancing around at the general camp area.

CFM_GaleAlone_32.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_32.text: Ah, finally he stirs. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.

CFM_GaleAlone_77.speaker: Narrator
CFM_GaleAlone_77.text: *Your previous encounter with the old wizard was most likely a simulacrum - the figure before you may well be too.*

CFM_GaleAlone_55.speaker: Narrator
CFM_GaleAlone_55.text: *Your previous encounter with the old wizard seems to have left him unflustered - and unmarked.*

CFM_GaleAlone_71.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_71.text: I took the liberty of enlisting your cadaverous co-traveller to revive you. You truly should take much better care of yourself, m'boy.

CFM_GaleAlone_30.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_30.text: The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.

CFM_GaleAlone_49.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_49.text: Say nothing. Wait for him to explain himself.

CFM_GaleAlone_14.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_14.text: Don't just gawp at me like the dregs of the fishmonger's stall - I've worn out quite some boot leather in order to track you down.

CFM_GaleAlone_13.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_13.text: I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.

CFM_GaleAlone_44.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_44.text: Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?

CFM_GaleAlone_47.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_47.text: But I suppose, after all the calamity that's been laid at your feet, you can be forgiven raw nerves and a sharp tongue...

CFM_GaleAlone_66.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_66.text: You underestimate me, Elminster. 'She' could be any number of acquaintances.

CFM_GaleAlone_1.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_1.text: But there is only one who truly counts, no? One whose favour you crave. One who knows the catastrophe that lurks 'twixt your ribs.

CFM_GaleAlone_38.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_38.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

CFM_GaleAlone_63.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_63.text: Mystra - the message and the charge I bring you are hers.

CFM_GaleAlone_10.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_10.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.

CFM_GaleAlone_11.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_11.text: She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.

CFM_GaleAlone_25.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_25.text: Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.

CFM_GaleAlone_61.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_61.text: You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.

CFM_GaleAlone_60.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_60.text: That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.

CFM_GaleAlone_21.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_21.text: You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.

CFM_GaleAlone_31.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_31.text: You promised me plain talk, Elminster. Make it plainer still, or we're done here.

CFM_GaleAlone_45.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_45.text: The orb. That constant reminder of your past failings. The instrument of your slow, sad, inevitable destruction. It can instead redeem you.

CFM_GaleAlone_73.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_73.text: I could possibly put an end to the Absolute - if you aided me.

CFM_GaleAlone_3.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_3.text: Alas, not the role I've been given in this particular tale. I am but a bare cameo compared to the part that you must play. You and the orb.

CFM_GaleAlone_27.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_27.text: Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.

CFM_GaleAlone_50.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_50.text: You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.

CFM_GaleAlone_17.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_17.text: I am Mystra's servant. If this is what she asks of me, so be it.

CFM_GaleAlone_57.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_57.text: Your clear-mindedness is a testament to yourself, Gale.

CFM_GaleAlone_43.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_43.text: That's the cost of Mystra's good graces? Martyrdom?

CFM_GaleAlone_52.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_52.text: Remember who she is, Gale. Mortal death is but a passing chapter to a goddess - and to those who win her favour.

CFM_GaleAlone_28.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_28.text: Whatever she can grant unto you is infinitely better than whatever you cling to now.

CFM_GaleAlone_23.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_23.text: With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.

CFM_GaleAlone_33.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_33.context: CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] He's disarming a magic orb within Gale's chest, close to his heart. Elminster gestures towards Gale's heart with an open palm, moving the hand in a small ircular motion, as if soothing or containing the orb within with a charm.

CFM_GaleAlone_22.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_22.text: It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.

CFM_GaleAlone_78.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_78.text: A shame that we did not cross paths sooner. The orb's thirst for magic is now quenched, yet it already inflicted some damage while you tried to forge ahead.

CFM_GaleAlone_2.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_2.text: The ill effects may linger, I'm afraid. Not enough to hamper your mission, I hope.

CFM_GaleAlone_5.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_5.text: Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.

CFM_GaleAlone_72.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_72.text: And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.

CFM_GaleAlone_18.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_18.text: Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.

CFM_GaleAlone_19.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_19.text: What other choice do I have?

CFM_GaleAlone_76.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_76.text: You could flee from Mystra's calling. Live the life of a hermit once again, and succumb to the orb all the same. Only, it will be a death without purpose.

CFM_GaleAlone_48.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_48.text: It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.

CFM_GaleAlone_26.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_26.text: That's more magnanimous of her than I've grown accustomed to. The catch being?

CFM_GaleAlone_59.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_59.text: The catch being the exact definition of redemption in Mystra's eyes, and the labour you must undertake in order to attain it.

CFM_GaleAlone_70.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleAlone_70.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

CFM_GaleAlone_64.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleAlone_64.text: You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.
CFM_GaleAlone_64.context: NodeContext: Weary resignation. He's being asked on a suicide mission.

CFM_GaleCom_28.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_28.text: Ah! There you are. I hope you don't mind my having ingratiated myself into the most palatable graces of your provisions. You find me quite sated indeed.

CFM_GaleCom_0.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_0.text: Mmm, yes, what a delightful wedge of Old Elturian that was. Doesn't do to parley on an empty stomach, you know. Makes one's words frivolous when they should be grave.

CFM_GaleCom_63.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_63.text: My thanks for your excellent guidance. Ah! And yonder I spy the object of my pursuit.

CFM_GaleCom_104.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_104.text: Ah, finally they stir. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.
CFM_GaleCom_104.context: CinematicNodeContext: Elminster is at camp when the players and Gale wake up.

CFM_GaleCom_62.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_62.text: Your friend here denied having the pleasure of your acquaintance, Gale, but I'll assume this feigned ignorance was committed with more or less noble intentions.

CFM_GaleCom_43.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_43.text: Come, come, up you both stand. I, for one, am dying to find out what's for breakfast.

CFM_GaleCom_47.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_47.text: Must have been his simulacrum you bested. He always was a cautious traveller.
CFM_GaleCom_47.context: InternalNodeContext: Aside, to the AvatarNodeContext: Referring to player previously 'killing' Elminster - it was an illusion. Low and an aside to the player, not meant for anyone else's ears

CFM_GaleCom_21.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_21.text: The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.

CFM_GaleCom_90.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_90.text: I don't understand. How so on my behalf?

CFM_GaleCom_73.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_73.text: I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.

CFM_GaleCom_31.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_31.text: But why? Out with it, Elminster. Please!

CFM_GaleCom_106.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_106.text: Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?

CFM_GaleCom_102.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_102.text: Nigh a tenday I've gone without honest fare worthy of the name - drank naught but what the sky entitled my thirst.

CFM_GaleCom_1.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_1.text: Why, some bread, cheese, and a cup of wine would appear unto me a feast! Surely you won't begrudge me a mite of rest and repast before I get 'out with it'?

CFM_GaleCom_77.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_77.text: Yes, Gale. Where is your decorum?

CFM_GaleCom_38.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_38.text: Surely you could have conjured any feast you liked.

CFM_GaleCom_26.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_26.text: Alas, such luxuries require the beneficence of time, and time, as I'm sure our friend here will attest, is the very luxury of which we're all too bereft.

CFM_GaleCom_67.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_67.text: Fine, fine, I'll turn a deaf ear to the clarion calls with which my scorned stomach beseeches me. Graver matters are at hand.

CFM_GaleCom_76.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_76.text: Plenty to digest, after all. A good deal to stew over, if you will. Words ladled with import should be savoured so as to better absorb their meaning, wouldn't you agree?

CFM_GaleCom_87.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_87.text: I, er... ahem. That is to say...

CFM_GaleCom_10.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_10.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

CFM_GaleCom_91.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_91.text: I'm here on behalf of Mystra. The message and the charge I bring you are hers.

CFM_GaleCom_93.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_93.text: It must be a great honour to be so entrusted by your god.

CFM_GaleCom_97.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_97.text: I could debate you on that.

CFM_GaleCom_48.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_48.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale, and I trust you've told your fellow traveller here the nature of your ills.

CFM_GaleCom_16.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_16.text: I can't say that so far I've volunteered the entire truth.

CFM_GaleCom_84.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_84.text: Do you mean to say you never bothered to disclose how dangerous you are?

CFM_GaleCom_81.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_81.text: Not in so many words, no.

CFM_GaleCom_50.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_50.text: Then you two have much to discuss after I'll have taken my leave.

CFM_GaleCom_29.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_29.text: In short, Gale - through his own doing - has become a living explosive that could wipe from this world this very gathering, and much more besides.

CFM_GaleCom_40.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_40.text: For his folly, Mystra forsook him, but now she has decreed he is to be given a chance of redemption.

CFM_GaleCom_45.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_45.text: She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.

CFM_GaleCom_24.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_24.text: Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.

CFM_GaleCom_74.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_74.text: If the goddess herself is aware, I wouldn't say no to some divine intervention.

CFM_GaleCom_8.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_8.text: The very purpose of my presence - in a roundabout sort of way.

CFM_GaleCom_27.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_27.text: You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.

CFM_GaleCom_65.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_65.text: That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.

CFM_GaleCom_60.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_60.text: Mystra is mistaken. I will be the Absolute's destroyer.

CFM_GaleCom_49.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_49.text: She'd do well to place her trust in me in equal measure.

CFM_GaleCom_55.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_55.text: I doubt not your conviction. But Gale has an unnatural advantage.

CFM_GaleCom_78.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_78.text: Hogwash. Idle beliefs and false hopes.

CFM_GaleCom_18.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_18.text: That which I speak of, as Gale well knows, is neither idle nor false. Rather it is... unnatural.

CFM_GaleCom_86.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_86.text: That which renders him so dangerous is an orb of Netherese origin that is buried within his chest. And that, Gale, is how we arrive at the heart of my directive.

CFM_GaleCom_100.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_100.text: Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.

CFM_GaleCom_88.speaker: GROUP_Daisy
CFM_GaleCom_88.text: Interesting. This could be help or hindrance - we shall have to see.

CFM_GaleCom_23.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_23.text: You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.

CFM_GaleCom_25.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_25.text: That's monstrous! You're tasking him to kill himself.

CFM_GaleCom_70.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_70.text: He is not. But it seems that Mystra is.

CFM_GaleCom_44.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_44.text: I'm surprised that Mystra demands such a sacrifice. This is hardly her way.

CFM_GaleCom_101.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_101.text: I'm glad it's not just me.

CFM_GaleCom_20.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_20.text: Say what you will, but you can't force Gale to go through with this.

CFM_GaleCom_71.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_71.text: No indeed. But I think she trusts me to.

CFM_GaleCom_42.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_42.text: We'll be rid of both the Absolute and Gale in one fell swoop. Win-win.

CFM_GaleCom_3.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_3.text: I may be slow to anger, but I will not have you sully this moment of most sorrowful import with ill-considered levity!

CFM_GaleCom_37.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_37.text: It's all right, Elminster. If ever gallows humour were appropriate, this is its grim-smiling hour.

CFM_GaleCom_15.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_15.text: It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.

CFM_GaleCom_59.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_59.text: With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.

CFM_GaleCom_75.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_75.context: CinematicNodeContext: Elinster speaks this spell and as he does so and makes hand gestures, a magical effect emanates from him and envelops Gale.

CFM_GaleCom_52.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_52.text: It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.

CFM_GaleCom_33.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_33.text: To you, I commit into care Gale himself. I count on you to shepherd him well on this strangest of journeys.
CFM_GaleCom_33.context: CinematicNodeContext: He addresses the player now, rather than Gale.

CFM_GaleCom_80.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_80.text: On my honour, it shall be done.

CFM_GaleCom_51.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_51.text: On my honour, I'm not sure yet I can say the same.

CFM_GaleCom_14.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_14.text: There's still a long journey ahead. We'll find another way.

CFM_GaleCom_41.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_41.text: Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.

CFM_GaleCom_2.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_2.text: And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.

CFM_GaleCom_32.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_32.text: Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.

CFM_GaleCom_96.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_96.text: Farewell, Elminster. I'm glad she chose you.

CFM_GaleCom_95.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_95.text: I am not his keeper, and I do not accept your charge.

CFM_GaleCom_92.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_92.text: Nor would I expect you to. It is too bleak a task to demand of anyone.

CFM_GaleCom_66.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_66.text: It sounds like the most insidious of evils was actually Gale all along.

CFM_GaleCom_83.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_83.text: By circumstance, but not by purpose, I swear. I never intended you any harm.

CFM_GaleCom_19.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_19.text: His acts were misguided, yes, but I assure you that deep down he has a heart of - let's say at least silver. Which is more than can be said for the foe you face.

CFM_GaleCom_7.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_7.text: If even the gods know, why are we facing these threats alone?

CFM_GaleCom_98.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_98.text: They choose the instruments of their will with great precision. Sometimes the single drops we think we are do not realise what waves we are building up to be.

CFM_GaleCom_17.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_17.text: Do not discount yourself, and by the same token, do not discount your enemy.

CFM_GaleCom_107.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_107.text: You wouldn't happen to know of a cure, would you? Some all-powerful, parasite-withering spell, perhaps?

CFM_GaleCom_46.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_46.text: Alas. The creature that afflicts you, the ill-begotten magic that it weaves, is inextricably conjoined with both the greater purpose and the greater master that it serves.

CFM_GaleCom_89.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_89.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.

CFM_GaleCom_22.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_22.text: You were sent here as an actual divine messenger?

CFM_GaleCom_109.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_109.text: Mystra's delicate feet are ill-suited for the hardships of the road.

CFM_GaleCom_99.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_99.text: I'm surprised she sent you in the first place after Gale's... debacle.

CFM_GaleCom_36.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_36.text: Thank you for that most considerate reminder.

CFM_GaleCom_64.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_64.text: What message and what charge would that be?

CFM_GaleCom_4.speaker: Gale
CFM_GaleCom_4.text: The long-awaited question. Now - if you please, Elminster - for the too-long-awaited answer.

CFM_GaleCom_58.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_58.text: Speak fast, then, for none of this pertains to me.

CFM_GaleCom_35.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_35.text: I suppose we could part with a few of our rations.

CFM_GaleCom_85.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_85.text: And a great kindness that would be! See, Gale? Even in these barren parts, the art of hospitality begets inspired new works if one only keeps up the practice.

CFM_GaleCom_54.speaker: Player
CFM_GaleCom_54.text: I'm not in the habit of taking in vagabonds.

CFM_GaleCom_57.speaker: Weary Traveller
CFM_GaleCom_57.text: Oh? And what is he, then, wandering these forlorn barrens over seven hundred miles from home?
CFM_GaleCom_57.context: CinematicNodeContext: On ‘he’, he points to Gale.NodeContext: On ‘he’, he points to Gale.
